Author: Lisa Hurley
Post Text: Since we’re talking about sister Taraji, can we also discuss how Mo’Nique said the exact same thing and got dragged to thy kingdom come?Can we talk about the literal shades of misogynoir?Can we talk about how Taraji’s message was better received because of colorism?Can we talk about how the reputational and financial losses that Mo’Nique suffered were closely related to her being being darker in hue and bigger in size?Can we talk about the fact that Taraji is taking home “regular money”? After everything is taken out and everyone is paid, there are probably quite a few folks right here on LinkedIn who take home multiples more than she does.Can we talk about the power of tears? Now do not read what I did not write. Taraji was and is clearly in deep pain and her tears sprung to her eyes spontaneously and authentically. I completely feel for and support my sis. That said, Monique, also in deep pain, delivered her message with a more stoic affect, and was perceived as being bitter; as being an “angry Black woman.”Can we talk about why we require Black women to be in literal tatters before we pay attention to their cries for help? Can we talk about how this is about the entertainment industry, but it’s not about the entertainment industry? Taraji, Mo’Nique, et al are us and we are them regardless of industry. I might go back through my posts at some point and show you how many times I’ve posted about pay inequity; about Black women needing to be supported, protected, and believed; about Black women and the Superwoman Syndrome; about the Angry Black Woman stereotype; about how no matter how we show up, we are harshly judged? Remember Justice Ketanji Brown Jackson and how she was verbally flayed for hours? Remember how Meghan Markle was treated? Remember how Auntie Angela (Bassett) was criticized for showing a little disappointment? These are women in the public eye, but trust and believe me that those of us “regular folk” are going through the same thing. The reason why so many Black women on this app are posting the Taraji video is because we know the struggle. Her tears are our tears. Every day…every single day…the struggle bus scoops us up and we go on a ride. And we have to show up in corporate spaces and smile, and be gracious, and be grateful for crumbs, and not rock the boat, and do wayyyy more while being paid wayyyy less. And say thank you for being overworked and underpaid.Just…no.Taraji also talked about building her own tables and diversifying her sources of income because she literally has no other choice.Look around you at the number of Black women who (like myself) are founders and solopreneurs. Yes, we have ideas that we want to bring to fruition, but also: we have to. The corporate machine chews us up and spits us out, and we choose to create better paths for ourselves. For every body who has ever asked me, with offense in their tone, why I center Black women, and why I created The Great Exhale™: this is why.

Post Text: I was born in Jamaica, and grew up in Trinidad and Barbados. 🇯🇲🇹🇹🇧🇧 Based on my Ancestry results I'm Blackity Black Black Black. (Mostly. Because slavery.)✊🏾✊🏾✊🏾✊🏾✊🏾✊🏾✊🏻A lifetime ago, I was a trained dancer.A lifetime ago, I was semi-fluent in French.A lifetime ago, I found myself living in France, teaching ESL. I missed dancing, so one evening I went out to shake a leg with a girl who had befriended me. We were cutting a rug in the bar, and then some Bob Marley came on. (They LOVE some Brotha Bob!!) Additional context:Phenotypically, she and her forbears hailed from the territories in Zhun of Caucay. It appeared that they had been existing, unseasoned, for centuries.Ok so…Bob Marley comes on, and my Jamaican, Barbadian, Trinidadian, rigorously trained dancer’s body starts moving to the music I have known my entire life. This pale person, who had taken one “Caribbean Dance” class, proceeds to tell me that I am “not doing the dance right.” She then took my hands in hers to guide me in the right way to dance to reggae. Because, you know…she had taken a class. 😐Jump cut to present day:This is how a lot of y’all – you know who you are – look and sound leading initiatives that are not yours to lead. This is how you look and sound on your monochromatic panels, regurgitating knowledge you stole from us, cosplaying thought leadership, getting paid for colonized content. This is how you look and sound calling yourself an ally, but engaging in harmful (not to mention condescending) behaviors.Your weekend course does not make you more qualified than those of us with lived, embodied experience. We are qualified by LIFE. Don’t make yourselves look ridiculous by trying to teach back to us what we already know. Don’t make yourselves look opportunistic by siphoning our experiences second-hand, and trying to profit from them.On this second day of Black History Month (and, tbh, in general), we implore you to:Shift back.Step aside.Cede the floor.This is our time.P.S. Agreed: “Not all,” but way too many. If it don’t apply, then scroll on by.P.P.S. You should already have booked (and PAID) your BHM speakers. You did pay them, right? Hopefully the word “exposure” didn’t factor into your discussions with them.P.P.P.S Running this one back from last year, cause it still applies. Which is kind of sad.Also: Black speakers don’t only “do” DEI. We are experts in a variety of fields and topics. Author: Lisa Hurley
Post Text: *TW: Mention of suicide*Pausing to mourn and honor Dr. Bonnie Bailey. May she rest in eternal peace.🙏🏾🙏🏾🙏🏾According to HBCU Buzz: "Dr. Antoinette “Bonnie” Candia-Bailey sadly passed away this week on January 8th. Family sources have officially confirmed Dr. Bailey died by suicide due to distress from “bullying and severe mistreatment” in her role as VP of Student Affairs at Lincoln University Missouri." Black women are under siege. Feels like we have always been.In terms of bullying and mistreatment; in terms of emotional, physical, intellectual, and financial attacks--none of this is new. Go as far back as the Black women who were operated on without anesthesia by the so-called "father of gynecology." Come as far forward as Dr. Claudine Gay, Justice Ketanji Brown-Jackson, Michelle Obama, Taraji P. Henson, Mo'Nique...the list goes on and on. Look around you at the Black women on this platform, in your office, in your circle...so many of us are suffering. So many of us hide that suffering behind our smiles. The details might differ, but the theme is the same. We all deal with the suffering differently, but mistreatment is the same. Many of us get to the point where we can no longer deal--or we get very close to it. We deserve to live. We deserve to enjoy life. We deserve so much better.Deepest condolences to Dr. Bailey's family and all who mourn her. 🙏🏾🙏🏾🙏🏾P.S. Employers, colleagues, allies: lend me your ears: be sensitive to the Black people in your circle. Many of us, especially Black women, are not feeling ok. Give space and show grace. 🙏🏾P.P.S. Black women: if you don't feel up to posting about this, that's ok. Take care of YOU. Don't let anybody try to force you into doing a post or even engaging with others' content about this if that's not what you want to do. Protect your heart. 🙏🏾🤎

Post Text: To Whom It May Concern: I am NOT paying y'all $3,500 to $6,000 to be featured in your bogus magazine. Not gonna happen. Post Text: Happy Black History Month. As you (you know who you are) get ready to put on your annual BHM Broadway-worthy performance, this is your reminder to absolutely acknowledge, honor, and celebrate Black History, AND support those who are currently making, or attempting to make Black History. Do not wait for people to become successful to support them, support them into success. Especially Black people who are pushing against a 400-year setback.So non-Black allies - individual and corporate - this is a call to you to do the work. And the work looks like hiring, promoting, and equitably remunerating Black people. (It also looks like making sure your culture is safe for them, but that's another post for another time.) It looks like recommending and referring Black people. It looks like supporting Black people in myriad ways, including financially. If there are Black people in your circle who have a company, side hustle, product, Patreon, book, course, subscription offering, consultancy, Etsy store, etc. then send some business their way. Make a purchase. Make a donation. Send them a little Zelle, PayPal, Venmo, or Cashapp love.Tag people...but also contribute. Make your support material and concrete.🟤 Share your resources. 🟤 Speak their names to powerbrokers.🟤 Get uncomfortable and give something up, e.g. : 🟤 Refuse to speak for BHM events - refer someone Black instead.🟤 Provide services and support as your contribution to their work.Put some skin in the game. Supply these mythical bootstraps we hear of. Ally is a verb.To my Black folks: Please share in the comments how people can support you. Drop your links. Share your info. Let your need and CTA be known. I've done this a few times in the past and people have benefited, so I'm hoping that it will work this time around as well. #BlackHistoryMonth#BlackHistory P.S. ♻️ Please share this widely and get the word out. P.P.S. Black History is also known as...History.

Author: Lisa Hurley
Post Text: To Black women. To whoever needs to hear it: we need you here. You are loved. 🙏🏾🤎🙏🏾As Justin says in this video: if you’re in a dark place, lean on community. Rest in your tribe. If you don’t already have it, find a community that will love, nurture, support, and embrace you as you deserve to be. Go where you are loved just as you are, without having to perform to gain approval.Seek comfort.As someone who has survived suicide attempts, I also have a message for “the village.” Please reach out. Please check in. Please stay in contact. If something feels off, it just might be. Make yourself a nuisance if need be, until the person who is in crisis is on a more even keel. Show up. Cook a meal. Do the dishes. Listen. Sit with them on the couch and share space. Help them find a therapist. Drive them there. There are so many ways you can help. This is a tough tough time…we need to be there for each other. We need to protect Black women. R.I.P. to Dr. Bailey, and condolences to all who mourn her. 🙏🏾🕊️🙏🏾

Author: Lisa Hurley
Post Text: "Why don't you talk about censorship and content suppression?" Someone asked me this recently, and I replied "I have. I've talked about it a lot. Just because you, new follower, don't see it happening doesn't mean that it hasn't happened in the past or isn't taking place now.”As the modern sage RaeShanda Lias-Lockhart says: "Let's check the board."I've been in the activism space consistently since 2020. Since that time I have written about some of the "big topics": racism, colorism, texturism, pay inequity, blackfishing (Google it), pet-to-threat syndrome, boundaries, microaggressions, greens, beans, potatoes, tomatoes, you name it. (#iykyk 😂) And I've had my content suppressed, and even sometimes deleted, more times than I can remember. I used to fight it. Occasionally I still do, but tbh I’m tired. Showing up and doing the work day in day out wears on one. Having to not only write, but also fight to be seen and heard adds another layer of static that I am simply not in the space to deal with. Sometimes self care looks like choosing the path of least resistance. 🙏🏾So though the algorithmic redlining still grinds my gears sometimes, I focus on putting my content out there, believing that whoever is meant to see it will see it. I do everything I can to give my posts the possibility of performing well, then I zen out and let it go. But make no mistake, just because I no longer actively spend hours of my life fighting censorship and shadowbanning doesn’t mean that I have given up. Like so many of my activist friends, I have decided that I will never remain silent, nor will I give any platform the power to silence me. ✊🏾✊🏾✊🏾 I will continue to speak out–on my terms. Look around at the Black creators in your circle, look around at the writers, activists, educators you follow, and you will realize that most if not all of us have built our own table. Actually, make that plural. Tables. We have multiple channels where folks can reach us and connect with us if we are deplatformed. We have websites, patreons, courses, blogs, newsletters, subscriptions, communities, myriad social media accounts. Tune in to our channels. My channels include:✔️ My blog on happyhappyphoenix dot com✔️ The TGE blog on itsthegreatexhale dot com✔️ The TGE newsletter ✔️ And, of course, my private membership community The Great Exhale.Part of the reason why I built TGE was to provide Black women with a space where they can post to their heart's content with no fear of being suppressed, no need to code switch, and no problematic Uncle Algo to contend with. Everything I do is part of the work.P.S. For those of you who are interested in how to fight back against being suppressed or censored, I wrote a blog post about it a few years back that’s still relevant today, so I’ll drop the link in the comments. P.P.S. Links for everything are in the comments.#TheGreatExhale

Author: Lisa Hurley
Post Text: Self-Care During Black History Month? Absolutely.Prioritizing self-care is revolutionary. Self-care is an act of resistance. ✊🏾🧘🏾‍♀️🤎Our ancestors did not literally slave and struggle only to see us continue to slave and struggle. So I invite you to celebrate Black History (aka History), AND take time to enjoy the present in a way that would make our ancestors happy. Many of them were forced to work. We can honor them by resting. We can honor them by doing less. We can honor them by treating ourselves with care and tenderness.As Audre Lorde said: "Caring for myself is not self-indulgence, it is self-preservation, and that is an act of political warfare.”  Inside The Great Exhale this is our main focus: self care as a revolt against all the isms; against the capitalist machine. Don't be fooled or distracted by the #SoftLifeVibes and what that means. When I launched TGE a few people became very upset with me because they read it as me being "too soft" and not being serious about the work. But this too is part of the work. Activism takes many, many forms.I'm super excited because today at noon eastern time we're having our monthly Collective Breath community check in. We're going to share. We're going to laugh. And we're definitely going to exhale. Can't wait. 😊🙏🏾💚🙏🏾😊 P.S. Bet you didn't know that the self-care as resistance movement started with the Black Panthers. Ask yourself why that part of history is rarely shared, and why the organization is presented in a pejorative way. P.P.S. Happy Presidents' Day to my forever President, Barack Obama.P.P.P.S. Want to exhale with us today? Post Text: This is about Jay Shetty, but it’s not about Jay Shetty. He is a symptom, kind of. We all need to be more discerning—maybe in different ways, but still. That has been one of my big lessons over the past 18 - 24 months. We need to be more like every basic website: verify humanity and authenticity first before proceeding; before drinking the koolaid. Cause scammers are gonna scam. If they shenan once, they’re definitely gonna shenan again. Everybody is not who they post to be.If they’re asking you to pay them to speak at their event: it’s a scam.If they’re asking you to pay to be on their Top Whatever list: it’s a scam.If they’re asking you to pay so they can lead you to the promised land: it’s a scam.If they’re asking you to pay to write a chapter in their book: it’s a scam.If they’re “priming the pump” and granting you favors only to require you to repay with your worldly goods, connections, and intellectual property: it’s a scam.If they’re asking you to pay in advance for what is supposed to be on the job training: it’s a scam.Et cetera, et cetera.They are counting on us to not be discerning, so we have to keep our antennas up.Be discerning. #Shenanigans

Author: Lisa Hurley
Post Text: I really want to post a happy "it's the first of December" post, but TBH that's not where I am mentally today. So I am doing what these companies advise us to do and showing up as my authentic self. And my authentic self is feeling sad.This year has been hard.It’s been one loss after another.It's been one betrayal after another.It's been one abandonment after another.People giving, but with shady intentions.People "helping," also with shady intentions.People attempting to erase me in various ways. People offering, then backtracking over and over again.People siphoning and even outright stealing, material items and in other ways. Bonus points cause they smile in my face and think I don’t know.There must have been a sale on sheep’s clothing, cause the wolves have dressed up and shown up in force.I would love to trust people, but time and again they show their underskirts and it’s not a pretty sight. I truly would get it if all these experiences were as a result of interactions with strangers. But no. It’s been from people close to me. The boogeyman is not a rando. The boogeyman is someone you know.So why am I sharing this here? I'm sharing because this is reality not just for me, but for many. The details might differ, but the experience is the same. I’ve spoken to a few of my actual friends as well as some acquaintances, and everyone is going through it. Don’t let anybody’s social media presence make you imagine that their life is more sparkly than yours. Somebody once told me that they want my life, and I was like…are you sure? Cause all the wonderful stuff (and there is lots of wonderful stuff) comes with all this difficult stuff. You get the rainbows, but also the shards of glass. There is no escaping that.So companies: when an employee shows up and they’re not grinning maniacally, remember that they have a whole life that does not involve you and that that their life might be life-ing. Once their work is getting done, leave them alone. And if they are having difficulty getting their work done, don’t assume laziness. They might be struggling and in need of help. Choose to help.I’m sharing this because people have asked me several times to be a part of their (insert activity), and gotten upset with me when I have said no. But I say no because in about 97% of cases that I say yes, some foolishness ensues. I have no time or emotional bandwidth to deal with anything more. I just can’t.No Footwerk Friday post will be forthcoming today. I’m going to immerse myself inside The Great Exhale, which is truly a haven for me as well as my wonderful community members. I know that will help me feel better. If you have any words of encouragement for me, I would really appreciate them. Thanks. 🙏🏾

Post Text: TAKE THE CAPE OFF. DO LESS. At work, at home, as we head into holiday/entertaining season...a reminder to take your superwoman cape all the way off, sis. Post Text: In Barbados🇧🇧 we call New Year’s Eve Old Year’s Night, a cultural nuance I have always loved. 💙🖤💛💙 So I spent a part of this morning preparing to say goodbye to the Old Year. Baptizing myself in nature. Washing away the unwanted and clearing energetic space to welcome wished-for blessings. Anointing myself in gratitude; processing and releasing grief.🙏🏾🙏🏾Given how hard this year has been, and what is happening in the world right now, I cannot fully enter into the spirit of celebration.  Just being honest.And yet…I have hope.I choose to persevere.I know Whose I am.I will carry on.Calling jen-know-cyde what it is is not complicated. But life in general is.Holding space and offering light to others who are struggling with the nuances of life. 🙏🏾🙏🏾🙏🏾 It’s ok to feel joy for your blessings; it’s ok to celebrate your accomplishments AND to find that joy tempered by existential grief for your fellow man. I have no New Year’s resolutions other than to keep going. The plan is to keep showing up. The plan is to “walk good.” The plan is to give myself permission to fully live, thrive, and exhale.That’s it.I’ll probably do a standard Happy New Year post at some point, but for now I’m wishing that everyone is able to make peace with their Old Year. I’m wishing everyone acceptance. I’m wishing everyone grace. I’m wishing everyone safety. I’m wishing everyone support. I’m wishing everyone love. I’m wishing everyone joy. I pray that your ships come in in the way you need them to.Happy last day of the Old Year.Asé 🙏🏾🙏🏾🙏🏾💨💨💨💨💨💨💨💨💨😎🤎 Hi, I’m Lisa, Founder of The Great Exhale™, an award-winning private membership community designed for Black women around the globe to collectively relax, lay their burdens down…and exhale.If that sounds like you, join The Great Exhale™ community today! 🙌🏾😊🤎💨 (Link is in the comments.)Ring my bell 🔔 so you don’t miss any posts, and follow my hashtags to catch all the vibes 😊:#ExhaleSis#TheGreatExhale#HappyHappyThoughts

Author: Lisa Hurley
Post Text: Happy International Women's Day! As we take time to celebrate all women today - as we should - I want you to take a close look at this image. Do you see what I see? Even in this standard illustrated collage, the woman with the darkest skin is right at the back. Also, it looks like the same outline was used for all of the women, so there are no ethnic differences in facial features. One does not want caricatures, but neither does one want erasive homogeneity.As my sister Sharon Hurley Hall (she/her) said earlier today: "#IWD could do with being a bit more intersectional and inclusive, don’t you think?"The theme for this year's IWD celebration is inclusion, but putting Black women at the back ain't it. If this is art imitating life, then life needs to change. Black women are tired of being pushed to the back.People have challenged me multiple times about - in their opinion - The Great Exhale being the opposite of inclusive. Not so. (I mean...who is doing the defining in this case? The people whose ancestors have spent generations excluding Black people and who continue to do so?) In The Great Exhale Black women are brought to the front. Black women are prioritized. Black women are celebrated. Our members know that they aren't there to check a box. They feel fully welcome, centered, and most importantly: included. I have been the Black woman in this image more than once. Pushed to the back so the powers that be can perform DEI and pat themselves on the back. I assure you that I did not feel included.My challenge to you is that if you are serious about "the work" then show up. Truly show up. Do your part to help the Black women in your circle and in your organization feel supported and prioritized. One way is to make it possible for them to enjoy a space like TGE where they are genuinely, not performatively, included. This month is IWD and next month is Black Women's History Month, so I'm inviting you to get involved in my #SupportABlackWoman challenge. Gift a TGE membership to a Black woman you know: in your company, in your family, in your circle. #OneGiftADay over the next 60 days would be awesome. There is no prize, lol. The prize is knowing you did the right thing.Support this Black woman-owned business, and support the Black women you know. Author: Lisa Hurley
Post Text: Do you ever look back at "younger you"? If so, what's your mood/tone/internal dialogue when you do? And what advice would you give to your baby self? It’s the beginning of the year, and I guess I’m feeling introspective, lol. (*Long post alert*)I was scrolling through some photos from back in the day and they brought a smile to my face. This one stood out cause it triggered so many great memories. 😊 I was in Antigua representing Barbados in a Caribbean beauty pageant. (Don't recall the name, but it was organized by the Jaycees. It was like 5,000 years ago. 🤣) I was proud to do so, but very nervous. I was happy because my chaperone was my Mom. She has always been my P.I.C., so I was excited that we would get to share this experience. I remember trying not to smile in this pic cause someone had teased me about how huge my smile was. 😂 So this was me trying to look dignified. I remember feeling proud and happy because my Mom had made most of my outfits. She was Project Runway before it existed. (She won the battle of "how high will the split be” btw. 😂). I remember doing my dance routine and feeling happy cause I had nailed it. 💅🏾 I also remember completely glitching out in the interview segment 🤣. That night anxiety and introversion won. But overall I remember feeling zen and contented. I did not win the crown, but I had truly done my best. So I was good. There were other contests that I had won (and that I would go on to win), but this time was not my time. And that was ok.So I look back at younger me with love and joy and grace.  🥰💗In terms of advice, I would tell her:💚 BE YOU. That’s your superpower. Don’t listen to dem people. Smile, dance, write, dress, BE however you want to be–unapologetically.💚 Embrace nuance and use greater discernment. Sometimes the vibe is “He who hesitates is lost” and at other times the vibe is “Doubt means don’t.” Pay attention to the signs.💚 In terms of people: trust, but verify. And verify. And verify. And verify. (Did I mention verify? 🤣)💚 Do it now. The time will pass anyway. If you decide, then execute.💚 Embrace your creativity. Your brain is a beautiful place.💚 Go where you are wholeheartedly celebrated.💚 Give, but keep some for yourself.💚 Take advice, but trust your gut.💚 Use what you already have.💚 Focus on your strengths.💚 Hold on to your magic.💚 Guard your heart.💚 Trademark that.💚 Let it go.💚 Say No.💚 Relax.💚 Ask.What advice would you give your younger self? Post Text: TFW allies show up as allies!! 😁🎊🙌🏾Since I am quick to berate those who indulge in performative allyship, let me be equally quick to recognize those who are truly about doing the work. People have to know that they are interacting with a real human being.Being focused and sticking to my lane has also served me well. I am known for writing and advocating around self care, pay equity, introversion, and a few other topics—and I stick to those. This helps to build trust and meet expectations. When I decided to found The Great Exhale it was not a surprise to anyone who had been following me for a while. It made sense for someone who is a Reiki Master, activist, affirmations expert, writer, and career creative to build a space and brand focused on healing and community care.Probably the biggest factor in building my reputation is doing what I agreed to do. One must be trustworthy and reliable. Author: Lisa Hurley
Post Text: GIVE IT YOUR “SOME”. Cause tbh, who has the energy to give it their all? 🤷🏾‍♀️🤣Black women especially: I encourage you to give it your some. Do the least. #DivestAndRest. Exhale. The first few days of the year have already felt like a month. It’s been a lot. We are grieving for Dr. Claudine Gay. We are grieving for Taraji. We are grieving for ourselves. We are grieving for our careers. Not all of us, but many of us. We might look in the mirror and see Dr. Gay’s face instead of ours. We might also actually be celebrating Dr. Gay’s decision to recuse herself from the tomfoolery; from the professional l￥nch!ng to which she was subjected. But even in the midst of feeling happy that she is now “free,” there might be a wistfulness as we face the truth around why she was forced to liberate herself. Many others more learned than I (John Graham and Kimberly Bryant come to mind) have posted about the fracas between Dr. Gay, Harvard, and the prevailing “anti-woke” school of thought. If you have the bandwidth, take a look at their recent posts. It’s an education. I decided to not post. At least not for now. That is my version of giving it my “some.” It’s January 5, and I’m already exhausted. So in this moment, self-care for me looks like not jumping into the fray. And that’s ok.So this Friday, and whenever you need it, I encourage you to conserve your energy for yourself. Not for a company. Not for strangers on the internet. For you. Give yourself permission to do less. Give yourself permission to rest. Give yourself permission to give it your “some.”Give yourself permission to:🙏🏾 Relax.🙏🏾 Vibe out.🙏🏾 Meditate.🙏🏾 Have fun. 🙏🏾 Take a nap🙏🏾 Practice self-care.🙏🏾 Decline those meetings.🙏🏾 Say yes to yourself. Author: Lisa Hurley
Post Text: Plagiarism vs. Inspiration. Context matters. Nuance matters. So here goes:This pic dates back to the middle of the panorama. The whole point (like Halloween) was to dress up as your favorite Met Gala star with whatever you had in your closet at home. In other words, the publicly stated brief was to imitate someone you were inspired by. It's no surprise to anyone who knows me that I chose RiRi. 🇧🇧👑 So this falls under the inspiration category IMHO.Similarly, we all have the same Internet. We're all ingesting the same news, jokes, TikToks etc., so: nobody robbed you of your gif, beloved. Nobody took your meme. Nobody stole "your" article from Google. (Remember when everybody was posting about Chairmageddon? Or how everybody is now posting about the Grammys? Exactly.) That said, it is always a good idea, if you have it, to include the source of the content you share. Naturally there will be times when you genuinely don't know the source, but once you know it, state it. What does not fall into either of these categories is a post I came across earlier today - "written" by a ghostwriter no less - that was a 95% copy & paste from someone else's post. This person is actually being paid for writing that they did not do. What does not fall into either of these categories is copying somebody else's words verbatim. It's a definite no-no. I allow grace for humanness. Nobody is perfect. Sometimes one is in a rush, or one forgets, or the platform glitches. But it takes work and multiple decisions to copy/paste, change "and" to "plus", and then not tag/cite the original writer. One of my connections here had that happen to her recently - literally thousands of people stole her content, and went viral based on her labor and intellect. They had a lot of energy and precision with the copy-pasting, but couldn't keep that same energy when it came to citing the source. They deliberately presented her thought leadership as their own. Whew. As an editor, people have tried to pass off plagiarized content to me before, and I don't need an app to tell me that that ain't their work. Ma’am. Sir. I am not new to this, so I know. One day you can barely string a sentence together and the next you're sounding like a Lit. professor? C'mon now. 😂 I mean…nice try, but I ain’t fooled. But even if I did not have years of experience and an eagle eye, some of y'all need to know that there are plagiarism checkers out there and we use them. We the editors. We the writers. We the professors. We check your work.In terms of AI, there is nothing wrong with using it, but again: we can tell. If you don't make any effort to spice it up with your own flavor, all we're thinking is "Wow, AI did a pretty good job." 🤣 Please add seasoning. Salt and pepper alone won't do. Lawrys. Old Bay. Pesto. Hot Sauce. Something. Unseasoned AI copy is flavorless and obvious.P.S. A.I. = Act with IntegrityP.P.S. That last paragraph is repurposed from my own content 🤣RiRi pic: Getty Images

Post Text: Have you ever just responded "ok" to someone's diatribe? I have. Strangers on the internet have tried to embroil me in arguments, and I simply refused. I declined to engage. There are times where one should engage/defend oneself, but in so many cases it's not necessary. Pointless arguments are not worth your time and energy. People are gonna think what they want to think anyway. 🤷🏾‍♀️ I came across this post below on Stacey Patton, PhD's FB, and it spoke to me:"In 2024 I am going to chronically deploy the following phrase that I just read on one of my threads: "You may now have the last word."I absolutely LOVE this.It is an acknowledgment of Futility.  An understanding that the argument has likely reached an impasse.  Further debate is  unproductive and there is no genuine commitment to a resolution.It says, "I am granting closure." You are offering the other person the "last word" as a graceful gesture and you are resigning from the argument and you prefer the harmonious echoes of peace. It also says that you recognize that the compulsion for having the last say is a silent plea for dominance -- a choreogoraphy of control rather than harmony.Say it with me: "You may now have the last word.""Via Stacey Patton and Blair NashHere's to peace. Here's to practicality. Here's to protecting your energy. Asé. 🙏🏾💨💨💨💨💨💨💨💨💨😎🤎 Hi, I’m Lisa, Founder of The Great Exhale™, an award-winning private membership community designed for Black women around the globe to collectively relax, lay their burdens down…and exhale.If that sounds like you, join The Great Exhale™ community today! 🙌🏾😊🤎💨 (Link is in the comments.)Ring my bell 🔔 so you don’t miss any posts, and follow my hashtags to catch all the vibes 😊:#ExhaleSis#TheGreatExhale#HappyHappyThoughts

Author: Lisa Hurley
Post Text: Black women are under attack, and have been for a long time. Stateside, across the pond, everywhere. It is devastating and traumatizing both individually and collectively. This is a longstanding humanitarian crisis. Like so many others of us, I will keep repeating this: we need safe spaces. This is why I created one. As it says in the groundbreaking Glitch Misogynoir Report: "Without safety for Black women, there is no safety for all." And if you don't understand that, you're part of the problem.Here's an excerpt: "Black women have been shouting from the rooftops about this issue for not just years but decades. The writing has been on the wall for some time, but some have turned a blind eye to it. The truth is, online abuse has only become an issue since it began to affect the Global North. Specifically white middle-class women, and some men. But tech, governments, philanthropists, the media, the police and civil society all need to listen to and start centring Black women’s experiences online when shaping policies and legislation." --Seyi Akiwowo, Founder of Glitch, whose mission is to end online violence and online hate speech against women and girls, and unapologetically centering Black women.The Glitch Misogynoir Report is a must-read. It includes an exposition of the current state of affairs, as well recommendations across industries and sectors for how to create policies, legislation, and corporate cultures that support online and real-world safety for Black women.Hat tip to Nova Reid for bringing this to my attention. Link to the report is in the comments.#WomensHistoryMonth

Post Text: This post by my sis • Theresa M. R. hit me hard today. Y'all have NO IDEA how tough this work is or the toll it takes on so many of us. Existing in 6f-majority spaces is bad for our health. Author: Lisa Hurley
Post Text: Maybe if someone else says it y'all will listen: "A lot of people offer someone unpaid work with zero return and that's raggedy." -- Luvvie Ajayi JonesThe reason why I preach the gospel of #FreeIsCancelled (shoutout to Mita Mallick and Dee C. Marshall) is not because I have never done anything for free. It's because I have, and have been taken advantage of. And that, alas, is the norm. I have paid my dues and that era is over.One time I was summarily "dismissed" from a job that I essentially volunteered at for several months. I spent countless hours (often 4+ per day in addition to my 9-5) building on behalf of someone else because I believed in the vision. The MINUTE I asked for help because the workload became too intense, my email account was shut down and I never heard from them again.  The minute I said "Why am I the only person on the team who is not being compensated?" I was dispensed with.Alas, this was not the only time. There are situations (few, though) where uncompensated labor is ok. But it must be, as my sis Alexis M. would say, bi-directional and mutually beneficial. I do podcast interviews, LinkedIn Lives, and various other promotional activities free. But one should not be expected to do EVERYTHING free. We cannot pay our bills with exposure.
